facts.text: Petition No. XVI of 1950 filed in Original Jurisdiction under article 32 of the Constitution for writ of prohibition and certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. XVI of 1950. Appli- cation under article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of prohibition and certiorari. The facts are set out in the judgment.

facts.text: Petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of weekly journal Cross Roads in English, printed and published in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: PATANJALI SASTRI J.--The petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of a recently started weekly journal in English called Cross Roads printed and published in Bombay.

facts.text: Government of Madras issued order No. MS. 1333 dated 1st March 1950 banning entry and circulation of Cross Roads in Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Madras, the respondents herein, in exer- cise of their powers under section 9  1-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949  hereinafter referred to as the impugned Act  purported to issue an order No. MS.

facts.text: Order published in Fort St. George Gazette prohibiting entry, circulation, sale or distribution of Cross Roads in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The order was published in the Fort St. George Gazette and the numberification ran as follows -- In exercise of the powers companyferred by section 9  I-A  of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order, Act, 1949  Madras Act XXIII of 1949  His Excellency the Governor of Madras, being satisfied that for the purpose of securing the public safety and the maintenance of public order, it is necessary so to do, hereby prohibits, with effect on and from the date of publication of this order in the Fort St. George Gazette the entry into or the circulation, sale or distribution in the State of Madras or any part thereof of the newspaper entitled Cross Roads an English weekly published at Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioner claims order contravenes fundamental right to freedom of speech and expression under article 19(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner claims that the said order companytravenes the fundamental right of the petitioner to freedom of See the headnote to Brij Bhushan v. The State of Delhi, p. 605 infra. speech and expression companyferred on him by article 19  1   a  of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitioner challenges validity of section 9(1-A) of Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949 as void under article 13(1).

anchor.surface_text: and he challenges the validity of section 9  1-A  of the impugned Act as being void under article 13  1  of the Constitution by reason of its being inconsistent with his fundamental right aforesaid.

facts.text: Case heard on May 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Rajah Ayyar, Advocate-General of MadraS,  Ganapathi Ayyar, with him  for the opposite party. 1950. May 26.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Patanjali Sastri J. for Kania C.J., Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of Kania C.J., Mehr Chand Mahajan, Mukherjea and Das JJ. was delivered by Patanjali Sastri J. Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali J. delivered a separate judgment. PATANJALI SASTRI J.--The petitioner is the printer, publisher and editor of a recently started weekly journal in English called Cross Roads printed and published in Bombay.

facts.text: Advocate-General of Madras raised preliminary objection to direct approach to Supreme Court under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of Madras appearing on be half of the respondents raised a preliminary objection, number indeed to the jurisdiction of this Court to entertain the application under article 32, but to the petitioner resort- ing to this Court directly for such relief in the first instance.

facts.text: Court rejected preliminary objection, holding Article 32 provides guaranteed remedy for fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that neither the instances mentioned by the learned Advocate General number the American decisions referred to by him are really analogous to the remedy afforded by article 32 of the Indian Constitution.

facts.text: Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949 (Madras Act XXIII of 1949) passed by Provincial Legislature under Government of India Act 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Act was passed by the Provincial Legisla- ture in exercise of the power companyferred upon it by section 100 of the Government of India Act 1935, read with Entry 1 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to that Act, which company- prises among other matters, public order.

facts.text: Court held section 9(1-A) void and unconstitutional as it falls outside Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: It fol- lows that section 9  1-A  which authorises imposition of restrictions for the wider purpose of securing public safety or the maintenance of public order falls outside the scope of authorised restrictions under clause  2 , and is there- fore void and unconstitutional.

facts.text: Court quashed the order prohibiting entry and circulation of Cross Roads in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The application is therefore allowed and the order of the respondents prohibiting the entry and circulation of the petitioners journal in the State of Madras is hereby quashed.

facts.text: Fazl Ali J. dissented, would dismiss the petition.

anchor.surface_text: FAZL ALI J.--For the reasons given by me in Brij Bhushan and Another v. The State 1  , which practically 605. involves the same question as is involved in this case, I hold that the reliefs sought by the petitioner cannot be granted.

issues.text: Whether this Court has jurisdiction to entertain the application under Article 32 directly or whether the petitioner should first resort to the High Court under Article 226

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General of Madras appearing on be half of the respondents raised a preliminary objection, number indeed to the jurisdiction of this Court to entertain the application under article 32, but to the petitioner resort- ing to this Court directly for such relief in the first instance.

issues.text: Whether the impugned order contravenes the fundamental right of the petitioner to freedom of speech and expression conferred by Article 19(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner claims that the said order companytravenes the fundamental right of the petitioner to freedom of See the headnote to Brij Bhushan v. The State of Delhi, p. 605 infra. speech and expression companyferred on him by article 19  1   a  of the Constitution

issues.text: Whether disorders involving menace to the peace and tranquillity of the Province and affecting public safety undermine the security of the State

anchor.surface_text: It appears to me that in the ultimate analysis the real question to be decided in this case is whether disorders involving menace to the peace and tranquillity of the Prov- ince and affecting public safety will be a matter which undermines the security of the State or number.

arguments.court_reasoning: Constitution distinguishes degrees of public order; only serious threats to State security permitted

arguments.claim: Sedition and public disorders both undermine State security; distinction untenable

holdings.text: The Court has jurisdiction under Article 32 to entertain the application directly; preliminary objection rejected as Article 32 provides a guaranteed remedy for enforcement of fundamental rights itself.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that neither the instances mentioned by the learned Advocate General nor the American decisions referred to by him are really analogous to the remedy afforded by article 32 of the Indian Constitution. That article does not merely confer power on this Court,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 32 is a fundamental right constituting the Court as protector of rights; not analogous to other concurrent remedies requiring exhaustion.

holdings.text: Freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a) includes freedom of propagation of ideas ensured by freedom of circulation; liberty of circulation is essential.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the merits, there can be no doubt that freedom of speech and expression includes freedom of propagation of ideas, and that freedom is ensured by the freedom of circulation. Liberty of circulation is as essential to that freedom as the liberty of publication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies textual interpretation and US precedents (Ex parte Jackson, Lovell v. Griffin) to hold circulation integral to speech.

holdings.text: The impugned order is a violation of Article 19(1)(a) unless saved by Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore perfectly clear that the order of the Government of Madras would be a violation of the petitioners fundamental right under article 19 1 a , unless section 9 1-A of the impugned Act under which it was made is saved by the reservations

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of expanded Art 19(1)(a) to ban on circulation.

holdings.text: Restrictions under Article 19(2) are limited to matters undermining the security of or tending to overthrow the State; public safety and maintenance of public order are wider and not covered.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that unless a law restricting freedom of speech and expression is directed solely against the undermining of the security of the State or the overthrow of it, such law cannot fall within the reservation under clause 2 of article 19,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitutional text distinguishes degrees of public order; IPC classification, legislative history, draft deletion of 'sedition' show narrow limits.

holdings.text: Section 9(1-A) of the Madras Maintenance of Public Order Act, 1949 is void and unconstitutional under Article 13(1) as it authorises restrictions beyond Article 19(2).

anchor.surface_text: It follows that section 9 1-A which authorises imposition of restrictions for the wider purpose of securing public safety or the maintenance of public order falls outside the scope of authorised restrictions under clause 2 , and is therefore void and unconstitutional.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overbroad authorisation for public order exceeds permitted security of State.

holdings.text: Section 9(1-A) is wholly void and not severable under Article 13(1); cannot uphold parts within constitutional limits.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accede to this contention. Where a law purports to authorise the imposition of restrictions on a fundamental right in language wide enough to cover restrictions both within and without the limits of constitutionally permissible legislative action

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overbroad language covers impermissible purposes; possibility of abuse makes entire provision unconstitutional.

holdings.text: The order prohibiting entry and circulation of Cross Roads is quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The application is therefore allowed and the order of the respondents prohibiting the entry and circulation of the petitioners journal in the State of Madras is hereby quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from invalidity of enabling section and violation of Art 19(1)(a).
